has the same meaning as would be. "What if I were you?"  or "What if I 
would be you?". So Was roughly equals Had been, while Were roughly equals 
would be.
comments.author: Andrew Cox

comments.text:
Pedro is right. Grammatically it would be "were," as the subjunctive "was" 
indicates that in fact "was" or was true in some time in the past, while 
"were" is to be used for hypothetical matters, such as, "What if this 
laptop were a desktop?"
But tbh it's negligible
comments.author: Bacon Sauce

comments.text:
Well, there's actually something called "grammatical moods" and it affects 
verbs. Hence my question.

In a sentence like this, the mood should be "Subjunctive" instead of 
"indicative" which is the most common. With the subjunctive "was" becomes 
"were", that's why the title of this video should be "What if the moon 
WERE..." and not "What if the moon WAS...", even though the "The moon WAS 
closer to Earth once.", because that's indicative.

Now, I know Michael Stevens (VSauce) has studied english literature back in 
college, so I assumed it is supposed to be that way. Still, most natives 
say/write it wrong, but as I trust Michael's knowledge, I don't know why 
it's written like that and would like to see an explanation.
comments.author: Pedro Henrique Köhler

comments.text:
when you are talking about singular third person perspective (he, she, it) 
you use was.

Yes, english is weird sometimes.

comments.author: Fortstorm

comments.text:
if you break it down to its core, the reason the moon does not crash into 
Earth is because of its relative velocity and angle. It's orbiting the 
Earth, and any pieces of the moon, or the disco ball would stay in orbit 
unless exceptional force was applied to it, making pieces escape the moons 
gravitational influence. The moon doesn't just fall apart due to its own 
mass holding itself together, and if some force was exerted upon it making 
it break apart, the same amount of mass would still be there, trying to 
pull it back together again. So: down to its core, you can't talk about 
something "falling" from the moon. It has to "ascend" from the moon with 
enough velocity to be able to counteract the momentum of the moon's orbital 
velocity and then be pulled towards the Earth.
The moon is not a disco ball on a string, hanging from a ceiling, unless 
you consider Earth to be that ceiling, and gravity to be the string holding 
the moon close, so it doesn't fly off into space.
comments.author: McJaews

comments.text:
+kill pill you're just reacting to the basic human instincts of fear of 
very large / gigantic objects.  Since humans are so small we get used to 
normal everyday objects such as pens, tv remote, watermelon, etc. to be of 
a "controllable" range -- things we have physical control over and can 
move, lift, carry, etc. using just our hands.  Conversely, large objects 
such as ships, airplanes are well -- large -- BUT it's still something we 
can control via a steering wheel.  GIANT objects such as planets, moons, 
and that space mirror is something we cannot control as in move, carry, 
lift, push, pull, etc... or at least not YET anyway.  Therefore it gives us 
a sense of lost of control and thus fear sets in to replace it.

comments.text:
+420RidetheLightning Omg necro, and no, you cant, let me say that again, 
you can not.  YOu can not achieve orbital velocity with an unpowered object 
period, unless you are already most of the way there.  For example, if you 
had sudamn husseins fancy gun, and you took it to orbital height and shot 
it 7.8km/s you would achieve an orbit with that bullet, but the problem 
with shooting it from earth is that you would get drag, and even if you 
didn't have drag for the first 24 hours the bullet would inevitably return 
to earth atmosphere on the other side of the planet, I would have to draw a 
picture to show you clearly what I am talking about, but basically, if you 
shot it too close to the horizon, it would just be in earth atmosphere 
until earth dragged it to the ground, if you shot it too high, it might 
leave space, but when it came back down it would just have performed a 
trans-orbital hop from where you are to another part of the world, in order 
to achieve an orbit, you have to make adjustments while you are in space, 
without them, an unpowered object would either crash back into the earth, 
or go zipping off into space, and how wonderful it is that we can't so 
easily create moons, because if it were as easy for us to have moons then 
we would have dozens of the asteroids that pass us either crash into the 
earth or the go zipping past us.

1. People who have too much time on their hands.

2. The earth is the perfect distance from the Sun. Any closer, we'd burn to 
death. Any closer, we'd freeze to death. If the Sun was where the moon was 
the earth would have been destroyed long ago.

3. If the ocean just suddenly turned to helium, a) That would throw off the 
balance of the elements in our atmosphere seeing as helium is dangerous to 
breathe in. b) If we didn't die from that our water supply would be short 
and all havoc would break loose.

4. The earth's core is in part responsible to gravity. We would just be 
floating around without it. Not necessarily good or bad. But the core is 
also responsible for our magnetosphere. This is an invisible force field 
around our planet which slims the chances of a foreign object colliding 
with our planet. No protection means death.

So pretty much, the answer to all your questions. Death. *nods*

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here. If we turned
the Moon into a giant disco ball,
day and night would not

be a disco party. Instead of diffusely
reflecting sunlight onto
all of us, a mirror-tiled moon would reflect
specularly. You would be lucky to momentarily
catch a single reflected beam of sunlight.

Now, with the help visuals by Nick from
Yeti Dynamics, who you should subscribe to

immediately, let's see what would occur
if a disco ball moon actually happened.

Here's the Earth with an imaginary
screen behind it, so we can track the
path of reflections

from a disco ball Moon. It's 3,012 mirror
tiles are ten kilometres thick
and between 100 and 150 kilometres
across. And, as you can see, the beams of sunlight they
reflect would only intersect with Earth briefly

and rarely - a few every month or so would
race past at more than 20,000 kilometers a second.

From the surface of Earth, they'd just be
tiny flashes in the sky
0.1 percent as bright as the regular Sun

and would last a fraction of a second.
The Earth, Sun and Moon just
aren't an ideal locations for disco ball effects.
But, if our disco ball moon was closer
and orbited earth not 384,000 kilometers away but

less than 450, as far as the
International Space Station does,
it would be torn apart by gravitational
title forces. Shoot. Also, the Moon doesn't really
rotate from our perspective like a fun disco ball.

It liberates, but it's starting to look
like instead of an awesome lunar party decoration,
a disco ball moon would just be a lunar party pooper.

So, for the sake of investigation, let's
allow this disco ball Moon to not be torn apart
and allow it to spin in the sky. Now we're talking.

Occasionally we would get glittery
reflections of a dimmer image
of the Sun. From the surface of Earth,
this is what we would see.
You know, being able to see
Earth reflected is almost cooler. It's like being
a bacterium on a giant's face who's looking into a mirror.
You can see the giant, but not yourself.
It kinda makes you feel small.
But it would be a great way to take planetary selfies.

So, let's watch a mirror the width of the
Moon orbit as close as the ISS does.
From the surface of Earth, it would look like this.

The strobe lights around the edge, by
the way, are ten kilometres across.
Pretty cool.

Now finally, let's take a look at the
Moon as a rotating disco ball from low orbit.
The Moon is not a disco ball
and likely never will be. It's just
a diffuse source of illumination. But it's

illuminating in a different way to imagine
what would occur
if that actually happened.
Woah.
And as always,
thanks for watching.

title: What if the Moon was a Disco Ball?
